bug.short_desc: [UX] Inconsistent error message levels with -e 1 vs -q

long_desc.thetext: # dnf -e 1 -d 0 -y update To diagnose the problem, try running: 'rpm -Va --nofiles --nodigest'. You probably have corrupted RPMDB, running 'rpm --rebuilddb' might fix the issue. This is very minor in the scheme of things, but in yum "-e 1" was meant to report all errors whereas in dnf it hints that there might have been an error but does not say what the error was - this makes the output somewhat nonsensical. If I run with -q instead, it also prints "Error: transaction check vs depsolve:" followed by the problem packages. Really, this transaction error message should have a lower "-e" value than the "to diagnose" message because that's just a hint and not a real error message. I realise that "-e" is deprecated in the man page, but it tells me to use "-v" instead and it's not clear how that's a valid replacement for reducing the error level. I suspect that "-q" is really what I want but it doesn't offer the same degree of control over the verbosity.

This bug appears to have been reported against 'rawhide' during the Fedora 25 development cycle. Changing version to '25'.

In dnf-2.4.1-1 ``-q`` means quet therefore the logger do not report anything to terminal, but it writes everything into logger files. Option -v show everything into terminal + the output is always written into logger files (/var/log/dnf.*log or /var/log/hawkey.log). In some cases this option provides additional verbose output like ``dnf repolist -v``. Unfortunately there are more users opinion how reports should be handled, therefore we cannot satisfy everyone.
